prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ALMA GOODS-S high-z sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We have selected a sample of galaxies in the CANDELS fields (the fields which are accessible by ALMA, i.e. UDS, COSMOS and GOODS-S) to be more massive than LogM* = 10.5 Mo and in the redshift range [3.5/5]. The sample is spanning about one dex in stellar mass, reaching up to LogM*~11.6 Mo and in total we have about 130 galaxies with accurately measured SEDs. We aim to detect 850um emission, corresponding to about 170um restframe at this redshift, that turns out to be a good proxy (0.2 dex scatter) for the star formation rate. This will provide us with the first dust unbiased estimates of star formation rates in the high redshift Universe. The main science driver is to understand if the secular mode of star formation, measured up to z~2, extends also to the early Universe. This specific science goal targets the high z sample selected in the GOODS-S field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our main goal is to obtain a dust-unbiased SFR estimate for a complete, mass selected sample of star forming galaxies at z~4. We have thus selected a total of 126 such galaxies in three of the deepest extragalactic fields, GOODS-South, CANDELS-UDS and CANDELS-COSMOS. We propose to use the unprecedented ALMA sensitivity in the sub-mm to get a continuum measurement for more than 80% of this sample.
# Correlator setup: To get robust LIR measurements, one needs to observe galaxies as close as possible to their FIR emission peak, i.e. around 90um rest-frame. We have chosen to observe in band 7, as it provides the optimal detection efficiency while being relatively close to the FIR peak (~170um rest-frame). Using our Herschel surveys at lower redshifts, we can show (see Fig. 2 left) that a single point measurement at this wavelength allows one to get a good estimate of the total LIR, with a dispersion of only 0.2 dex. In order to maximize the detection efficiency, we do not want our sources to be resolved, but we still need a good enough resolution so that close pairs are not misidentified as single objects. It has been shown with Hubble high resolution images that the mean UV restframe half-light radius of a z~4 galaxy is 0.25" (Ferguson et al. 2003). We thus securely aim at a 0.7" resolution, which will leave most if not all of our sample unresolved. Finally, we have tuned the sky frequency of our observations in order to maximise the number of galaxies with spectroscopic redshift for which the [CII] emission would fall in one of the basebands. Using the LFIR to L[CII] correlation (Diaz-Santos et al. 2013), we expect a handful to be detected.
# Requested sensitivity: Galaxies in this redshift range have never been observed with surveys deep enough to detect "normal" star forming objects. Indeed, single dish observations -- with instruments such as Herschel, SCUBA, LABOCA or AzTEC -- have only seen the tip of the iceberg, only detecting the most star forming "monsters" at these redshift. Yet, we can still provide a good estimate of the median FIR properties of our sample by stacking Herschel images (see Fig. 3 right), in order to derive median LIR and Tdust. This analysis, carried out from low to high redshift (see Fig. 1), suggests that the SFR - M* correlation, the so called "main sequence" of star formation, holds at all redshifts at least up to z~4. Assuming this is true, and that the observed 0.3 dex scatter of this relation does not evolve much with redshift, we have estimated a SFR for every galaxy in our sample by adding a random offset to the derived main sequence SFR, inferred from their redshifts and stellar masses, along with a FIR SED based on the stacked one. By construction, we do not expect these simulated properties to be anywhere close to the real properties of each individual galaxy, but they nevertheless provide a solid statistical estimation for the sample as a whole. Using these, we can thus predict the ALMA sensitivity that would allow us to detect about 80% of those galaxies, which we found to be 0.2 mJy RMS (see Fig. 2 right).
# Source list: We have checked for duplicate sources against Cycle 0 and Cycle 1 observations. In GOODS South, two sources in our sample have already been observed by ALESS (PI: I. Smail) with sufficient SNR and resolution. However, one of these is close to two other sources that were not detected in the ALESS pointing, either because of the poor sensitivity or because they were too off-centered. We thus plan to re-observe this region in order to detect these two possibly fainter sources, and the ALESS source will be in the FOV. The other ALESS source has been removed. We have also discarded two sources that are part of the Mullaney et al. CDFS proposal in Cycle 1, and that are to be observed with the same sensitivity.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ALMA CANDELS-UDS high-z sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We have selected a sample of galaxies in the CANDELS fields (the fields which are accessible by ALMA, i.e. UDS, COSMOS and GOODS-S) to be more massive than LogM* = 10.5 Mo and in the redshift range [3.5/5]. The sample is spanning about one dex in stellar mass, reaching up to LogM*~11.6 Mo and in total we have about 130 galaxies with accurately measured SEDs. We aim to detect 850um emission, corresponding to about 170um restframe at this redshift, that turns out to be a good proxy (0.2 dex scatter) for the star formation rate. This will provide us with the first dust unbiased estimates of star formation rates in the high redshift Universe. The main science driver is to understand if the secular mode of star formation, measured up to z~2, extends also to the early Universe. This specific science goal targets the high z sample selected in the CANDELS-UDS field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our main goal is to obtain a dust-unbiased SFR estimate for a complete, mass selected sample of star forming galaxies at z~4. We have thus selected a total of 126 such galaxies in three of the deepest extragalactic fields, GOODS-South, CANDELS-UDS and CANDELS-COSMOS. We propose to use the unprecedented ALMA sensitivity in the sub-mm to get a continuum measurement for more than 80% of this sample.
# Correlator setup: To get robust LIR measurements, one needs to observe galaxies as close as possible to their FIR emission peak, i.e. around 90um rest-frame. We have chosen to observe in band 7, as it provides the optimal detection efficiency while being relatively close to the FIR peak (~170um rest-frame). Using our Herschel surveys at lower redshifts, we can show (see Fig. 2 left) that a single point measurement at this wavelength allows one to get a good estimate of the total LIR, with a dispersion of only 0.2 dex. In order to maximize the detection efficiency, we do not want our sources to be resolved, but we still need a good enough resolution so that close pairs are not misidentified as single objects. It has been shown with Hubble high resolution images that the mean UV restframe half-light radius of a z~4 galaxy is 0.25" (Ferguson et al. 2003). We thus securely aim at a 0.7" resolution, which will leave most if not all of our sample unresolved. Finally, we have tuned the sky frequency of our observations in order to maximise the number of galaxies with spectroscopic redshift for which the [CII] emission would fall in one of the basebands. Using the LFIR to L[CII] correlation (Diaz-Santos et al. 2013), we expect a handful to be detected.
# Requested sensitivity: Galaxies in this redshift range have never been observed with surveys deep enough to detect "normal" star forming objects. Indeed, single dish observations -- with instruments such as Herschel, SCUBA, LABOCA or AzTEC -- have only seen the tip of the iceberg, only detecting the most star forming "monsters" at these redshift. Yet, we can still provide a good estimate of the median FIR properties of our sample by stacking Herschel images (see Fig. 3 right), in order to derive median LIR and Tdust. This analysis, carried out from low to high redshift (see Fig. 1), suggests that the SFR - M* correlation, the so called "main sequence" of star formation, holds at all redshifts at least up to z~4. Assuming this is true, and that the observed 0.3 dex scatter of this relation does not evolve much with redshift, we have estimated a SFR for every galaxy in our sample by adding a random offset to the derived main sequence SFR, inferred from their redshifts and stellar masses, along with a FIR SED based on the stacked one. By construction, we do not expect these simulated properties to be anywhere close to the real properties of each individual galaxy, but they nevertheless provide a solid statistical estimation for the sample as a whole. Using these, we can thus predict the ALMA sensitivity that would allow us to detect about 80% of those galaxies, which we found to be 0.2 mJy RMS (see Fig. 2 right).
# Source list: We have checked for duplicate sources against Cycle 0 and Cycle 1 observations. In UDS, one of our sources is located at less than 5" of a pointing from Smail et al., that is scheduled for carried over Cycle 1 with the same sensitivity, and has thus been discarded from the present sample. We have also combined together two close sources distant by 0.7" in a single pointing.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: ALMA CANDELS-COSMOS high-z sample
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We have selected a sample of galaxies in the CANDELS fields (the fields which are accessible by ALMA, i.e. UDS, COSMOS and GOODS-S) to be more massive than LogM* = 10.5 Mo and in the redshift range [3.5/5]. The sample is spanning about one dex in stellar mass, reaching up to LogM*~11.6 Mo and in total we have about 130 galaxies with accurately measured SEDs. We aim to detect 850um emission, corresponding to about 170um restframe at this redshift, that turns out to be a good proxy (0.2 dex scatter) for the star formation rate. This will provide us with the first dust unbiased estimates of star formation rates in the high redshift Universe. The main science driver is to understand if the secular mode of star formation, measured up to z~2, extends also to the early Universe. This specific science goal targets the high z sample selected in the CANDELS-COSMOS field.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Our main goal is to obtain a dust-unbiased SFR estimate for a complete, mass selected sample of star forming galaxies at z~4. We have thus selected a total of 126 such galaxies in three of the deepest extragalactic fields, GOODS-South, CANDELS-UDS and CANDELS-COSMOS. We propose to use the unprecedented ALMA sensitivity in the sub-mm to get a continuum measurement for more than 80% of this sample.
# Correlator setup: To get robust LIR measurements, one needs to observe galaxies as close as possible to their FIR emission peak, i.e. around 90um rest-frame. We have chosen to observe in band 7, as it provides the optimal detection efficiency while being relatively close to the FIR peak (~170um rest-frame). Using our Herschel surveys at lower redshifts, we can show (see Fig. 2 left) that a single point measurement at this wavelength allows one to get a good estimate of the total LIR, with a dispersion of only 0.2 dex. In order to maximize the detection efficiency, we do not want our sources to be resolved, but we still need a good enough resolution so that close pairs are not misidentified as single objects. It has been shown with Hubble high resolution images that the mean UV restframe half-light radius of a z~4 galaxy is 0.25" (Ferguson et al. 2003). We thus securely aim at a 0.7" resolution, which will leave most if not all of our sample unresolved. Finally, we have tuned the sky frequency of our observations in order to maximise the number of galaxies with spectroscopic redshift for which the [CII] emission would fall in one of the basebands. Using the LFIR to L[CII] correlation (Diaz-Santos et al. 2013), we expect a handful to be detected.
# Requested sensitivity: Galaxies in this redshift range have never been observed with surveys deep enough to detect "normal" star forming objects. Indeed, single dish observations -- with instruments such as Herschel, SCUBA, LABOCA or AzTEC -- have only seen the tip of the iceberg, only detecting the most star forming "monsters" at these redshift. Yet, we can still provide a good estimate of the median FIR properties of our sample by stacking Herschel images (see Fig. 3 right), in order to derive median LIR and Tdust. This analysis, carried out from low to high redshift (see Fig. 1), suggests that the SFR - M* correlation, the so called "main sequence" of star formation, holds at all redshifts at least up to z~4. Assuming this is true, and that the observed 0.3 dex scatter of this relation does not evolve much with redshift, we have estimated a SFR for every galaxy in our sample by adding a random offset to the derived main sequence SFR, inferred from their redshifts and stellar masses, along with a FIR SED based on the stacked one. By construction, we do not expect these simulated properties to be anywhere close to the real properties of each individual galaxy, but they nevertheless provide a solid statistical estimation for the sample as a whole. Using these, we can thus predict the ALMA sensitivity that would allow us to detect about 80% of those galaxies, which we found to be 0.2 mJy RMS (see Fig. 2 right).
# Source list: We have checked for duplicate sources against Cycle 0 and Cycle 1 observations. In COSMOS, none of our sources were already observed or scheduled at the same frequency range. We have combined together two close sources distant by 1.2" in a single pointing.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: In recent years, convincing evidence have been accumulated that galaxies built up their stellar mass through a steady, diffuse and inefficient gas conversion dominantly taking place in non-interacting disk dominated galaxies. This has been confirmed at least up to z~3, beyond that even the deepest Herschel and JVLA surveys are not able to probe deep enough in L_IR sensitivity to detect normal massive galaxies. Thanks to exceptional ALMA sensitivity we are now in the position to easily detect a statistical sample of normal star forming galaxies at z~4 and test, for the first time, if the secular mode of stellar mass growth extends over all cosmic time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
